About this workbook

This workbook will serve as your textbook for this course. It is organized into seven sections—one for each week of the course. You will learn about each week’s topic by reading through the assigned weekly content and completing the activities within each section. You only need to access Canvas to take the weekly quizzes and submit your assignments by the due dates.

About GESCI 110

Welcome to GESCI 110: Sustaining Human Life! This course is designed to help you answer this question: How do we feed and care for a growing world population? 

 

This course addresses two crucial and compelling questions facing the world: how will we feed 9 billion people by the year 2050, and how will we care for those 9 billion people? You will investigate the challenges and opportunities involved with creating a sustainable food supply, promoting healthy lifestyles, and providing health care for everyone. Through your own sustaining life project, you will teach and bless others in your community. This course has the potential to change the world as each student strives to increase their knowledge and implement positive change wherever they live.  

 

Through the activities of this course, you will be able to do the following: 

●      Explain the strengths and limitations of the scientific process as a source of knowledge. 

●      Identify engaging fields of study with good career potential. 

●      Analyze compelling and important questions using scientific evidence. 

●      Discuss challenging issues in a respectful and productive manner. 

 

We hope you will enjoy learning more about our role as stewards to continue sustaining and improving the lives of individuals and communities of the world.

Find and Cite Sources

Citing sources is a critical part of showing support for a claim being made.

 

As a writer, you will cite sources to help show where you got your information and to support your arguments. You will also cite sources to properly attribute the authors of the information. Write all answers in your own words unless quoting is required by the instructions

 

As a reader, you will use citations to learn more about the information you are learning. You can check the citations of any publication to help you evaluate the credibility of a source. If a publication doesn't have sources, that doesn't mean it is wrong, but it does help you know how to interpret the reliability of the information.

●      Wikipedia is not a credible source and is not allowed as a citation on assignments.

●      Links that include artificial intelligence (AI) websites are not allowed. Please review the AI class policy in the next section. Example, a website ending with “chatgpt.com”

●      When citations are required as part of assignments, use the APA Style 7 Edition.

●      Make sure all website links are working hyperlink to an accessible source page where the specific information can be found.

●      Clarify credible sources for this course:

●      The official website of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints qualifies as a credible source based on the origin, purpose, and mission of BYU-Idaho.

○      Only a working, related hyperlink with "ChurchofJesusChrist" in the URL will qualify for credit.

●      ChurchofJesusChrist.org is the only faith-based website that will earn credit as a credible source.

●      All other sources must meet all or most of the 3R criteria to qualify as a credible source.

 

How To Use Artificial Intelligence (AI) as a Tool for Success in GESCI110 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) includes programs such as ChatGPT, Microsoft CoPilot/Bing Chat, Bard, Grammarly, etc.. These programs allow you to ask a question and receive a response from the AI, with the AI generating content through back-and-forth dialogue in real-time. AI may be a valuable resource for exploring a new topic, brainstorming ideas or even providing useful information—when that information can be verified independently as factual. (AI is well-known for creating sources that look and sound authentic but are fake.)

In the BYU Pathway document on Academic Integrity and Artificial Intelligence, it says the following, “The courses you take have specific outcomes and objectives concerning your progress as a student. Critical thinking and analytical skills are fundamental to success in most employment environments and are key skills gained in a university education. Using AI tools as a shortcut to circumvent the critical thinking and analysis required to complete assignments is not only a violation of academic integrity but it shortchanges the learning process.” 

 

The course outcomes for GESCI 110 are heavily based on critical thinking and developing the ability to determine the reliability of outside sources. AI cannot do this for you. Therefore, we are not interested in developing your skills utilizing artificial intelligence in this class. We are focused on developing your intelligence, your critical thinking, and building your skills to promote sustainable, healthy living. 

 

To that end, AI should never be used to produce writing for which you receive credit. Using AI to create any portion of your submitted work (including language translation and spelling check)  is plagiarism and grounds for failing the assignment and the course. 

 

Do not use AI to produce your writing for this class. We want to hear your ideas, not AI’s.

W01 Study: Ways of Knowing Truth

At the end of this section, students will be able to: 

●      Understand the problem

●      Address how you feed and care for 9 billion people by 2050. 

●      Ways of Knowing

●      Identify revelation and the scientific method as methods for accessing truth. 

●      Understand the scientific process. 

●      Identify valid applications of the scientific process. 

●      Explain how we can use the scientific method to solve problems.  

The goal this first week is to introduce you to the primary question addressed in this class: How do we feed and care for a growing population? We will also set the foundation of how to evaluate difficult questions. 

 

Addressing Population Growth.

Why is it important that we focus on people as individuals (“the one”) rather than as numbers as the population continues growing? 

By 2050, the world's population is projected to reach 9 billion people. This exponential growth presents a formidable challenge, as we must find sustainable ways to provide food, water, and resources for everyone. Access to nutritious food and equitable health care will become even more essential to ensure that individuals not only survive but thrive. Understanding the magnitude of this challenge is the first step towards finding solutions. In addressing population growth, it's crucial to shift our perspective from viewing people as mere statistics to recognizing everyone’s inherent worth and dignity. By focusing on the needs of individuals ("the one"), we can better understand the complexities of population growth and our responsibilities towards one another as stewards of the Earth.

In our quest to understand the world and address complex challenges, we rely on various methods for accessing truth. In this chapter, we'll explore two primary methods: revelation and the scientific method.

 

Revelation vs Scientific Method

What types of questions are best answered by revelation?  

Revelation, often associated with spiritual or divine insights, provides a source of truth that goes beyond empirical evidence. On the other hand, the scientific method relies on observation, experimentation, and logical reasoning to uncover truths about the natural world. While both methods have their strengths and limitations, they complement each other in our search for knowledge and understanding.

In terms of the scientific method, its power comes from its ability to provide empirical evidence and test hypotheses through systematic experimentation. Systematic experimentation involves manipulating variables, collecting data, and analyzing results to determine if they support or contradict a hypothesis. The method is most effective in uncovering natural laws and understanding the physical world. However, the scientific method has limitations, such as the inability to answer questions related to moral, spiritual, and eternal truths. While science can provide valuable insights, it is not the sole source of knowledge and should be complemented by other forms of truth-seeking, such as revelation.

While we acknowledge and value revelation as a valid means of uncovering truth, our primary focus will be on the scientific method and scientific sources in this class. The scientific method serves as the foundation of our inquiry, providing a systematic framework for investigating natural phenomena, testing hypotheses, and expanding our understanding of the world around us. By emphasizing the scientific method, we aim to cultivate critical thinking skills, promote evidence-based reasoning, and instill a rigorous approach to inquiry essential for scientific exploration and discovery.

While our focus in this class will be on scientific inquiry, we do not diminish the importance of personal and prophetic revelation in the broader context of seeking truth. Instead, we seek to foster a balanced perspective that acknowledges the complementary nature of scientific exploration and spiritual insight in the pursuit of knowledge and enlightenment. Through this holistic approach, we strive to cultivate a deeper appreciation for the multifaceted ways in which truth can be uncovered and understood.

Scientific Method

What types of questions are best answered through science? 

Science is best suited for addressing questions related to the natural world, physical phenomena, and empirical observations. It can provide insights into the properties of matter, the behavior of physical systems, and the mechanisms underlying natural phenomena.

For example, through the scientific method, humanity has gained a deeper understanding of the natural world, leading to advancements in technology, medicine, agriculture, and other fields. These advancements have improved living standards, enhanced quality of life, and alleviated suffering for countless individuals. Scientific research has led to innovations such as medical treatments, communication technologies, and environmental conservation efforts, contributing to the well-being and progress of society. Additionally, the scientific method has fostered a spirit of inquiry, innovation, and collaboration, driving continued exploration and discovery in pursuit of knowledge, and understanding.

Understanding the Scientific Process

How does the scientific process work? 

The scientific method is a systematic approach used by scientists to investigate natural phenomena, acquire new knowledge, and test hypotheses. It involves a series of steps designed to ensure objectivity, reliability, and reproducibility in scientific inquiry. While variations exist, the basic steps of the scientific method typically include:

●      Observation: The process begins with making observations or asking questions about a particular phenomenon or problem. This may involve gathering data, conducting surveys, or examining existing information.

●      Hypothesis: Based on observations, a hypothesis is formulated. A hypothesis is a tentative explanation or prediction that can be tested through experimentation.

●      Prediction: A hypothesis is used to make predictions about the outcome of experiments or observations. These predictions are then tested.

●      Experimentation: Controlled experiments are conducted to test the validity of the hypothesis and evaluate its predictions. Experiments involve manipulating variables, collecting data, and analyzing results to determine if they support or contradict the hypothesis.

●      Analysis: Data collected during experiments are analyzed using statistical methods or other techniques to identify patterns, trends, or relationships. This step involves interpreting the results and drawing conclusions based on evidence.

●      Conclusion: Based on the analysis of data, scientists draw conclusions about the validity of the hypothesis. If the evidence supports the hypothesis, it may be considered valid and accepted. If the evidence contradicts the hypothesis, it may be revised or rejected in favor of alternative explanations.

●      Communication: Scientists communicate their findings through publications, presentations, or peer-reviewed journals. This allows other researchers to review, replicate, and build upon the research, contributing to the collective body of scientific knowledge.

The scientific method is iterative, meaning that it involves repeated cycles of observation, hypothesis formation, experimentation, and analysis. Through this process, scientific knowledge evolves and expands, leading to a deeper understanding of the natural world.

Social Media: the anti-scientific method

What are some differences between information presented on social media versus scientific research?  

Today, social media is everywhere and shapes how people share and take in information. But it’s important to see that social media works very differently from science. Science uses careful tests, evidence, and review to find the truth. Social media, on the other hand, often focuses on what spreads quickly, what seems exciting, or what is most popular—even if it hasn’t been checked. Social media can contain posts with scientifically accurate information, but there is no mechanism to ensure that what is posted is accurate, and often it is not.

This difference matters because false information and fake science can spread fast online. This can cause people to misunderstand facts, lose trust in experts, or even make harmful choices. Science depends on questioning, careful thinking, and testing ideas. Social media, however, can create echo chambers, push confirmation bias, and make misleading stories louder.

That’s why it’s so important to understand how social media and science are not the same. By building digital literacy, practicing critical thinking, and learning to question what we see online, people can avoid being misled and protect the role of science in today’s connected world.

Evaluating Scientific Resources

●      Why is it important to evaluate scientific resources?  

●      What are some of the things you should look for when evaluating a scientific article?  

●      Define the Three Rs of analyzing scientific claims. 

 

Even though science can answer important questions, it is crucial to understand that not all scientific information is created equal. Therefore, we need to be sure that we evaluate all scientific resources. Evaluating scientific resources is crucial for several reasons:

●      Accuracy and Reliability: By evaluating resources, researchers can ensure that the information they are using is accurate, reliable, and based on sound scientific principles. This helps prevent the spread of misinformation and ensures conclusions drawn from scientific research are trustworthy.

●      Validity of Findings: Evaluation helps determine the validity of research findings and conclusions. By assessing the methodology, data collection techniques, and analysis methods used in a study, researchers can determine whether the results are robust and supported by evidence. This is essential for building upon existing knowledge and drawing meaningful conclusions from scientific research.

●      Peer Review: Many reputable scientific journals employ a peer-review process, where experts in the field critically evaluate research articles before publication. Evaluating scientific resources involves considering whether a study has undergone peer review and assessing the credibility of the journal or publication in which it appears. Peer-reviewed research is generally considered more reliable and trustworthy.

●      Bias and Conflicts of Interest: It is essential to consider potential biases or conflicts of interest that may influence scientific research. Evaluating resources involves examining the funding sources, affiliations, and potential conflicts of interest of the researchers or institutions involved in the study.  This helps ensure that research findings are not unduly influenced by external factors and that scientific integrity is maintained.

●      Relevance to Research Question: Evaluating resources involves assessing whether the information presented is relevant to the research question or topic of interest. Researchers need to consider whether a study's methodology, sample size, and conclusions align with their research objectives and whether the findings are applicable to their specific context or field of study.

Overall, evaluating scientific resources is essential for maintaining the integrity of scientific research, ensuring the validity of findings, and advancing knowledge in a responsible and evidence-based manner. It empowers researchers to make informed decisions, critically analyze information, and contribute to the collective body of scientific knowledge.

To break down the process more simply, we will evaluate scientific resources using a method called the three Rs: Reliable, Reproducible, and Rational.

Reliable 

●      Does the author or organization writing the material have good credentials relating to the topic that is being written about? 

●      Are good references cited (preferably from peer-reviewed sources)? 

●      If the material is an article, is it peer-reviewed or, if you are looking at a website, does the domain name indicate credibility? 

Reproducible 

●      Is the information based on data and research? 

●      Have the conclusions stated in the material been reproduced and are they supported by the majority of the research in this area? 

Rational 

●      Is the information presented in a balanced way (or does it sound too good to be true)? 

●      Are the authors free of a conflict of interest? 

●      Is the content well-written and free from an emotional agenda? 

●      Is the information consistent with revealed truth that may be available on the topic?

W01 Study: Climate, Weather, Soils, and Stewardship

At the end of this section, students will be able to:

o   Describe the conditions necessary for plants to grow and be productive.  

o   Describe the factors impacting the likelihood of plants being grown in certain geographical areas (rain, temperature, economics, transportation, marketability, and so on).

o   Define soil and describe its components. 

o   Understand soil forming factors and how humans impact soil formation. 

 

Where Can or Should We Grow Our Food?  

Cities are spreading, and new houses are filling the surrounding areas. Farms are further from city centers, and many are being converted to non-productive land. Also, some regions of the earth are growing hotter, and are not suitable for crops grown there historically. Modern agriculture uses more resources and produces more waste. With the changes taking place around the world, where can or should we grow our food? 

 

Climate, Weather, Soils, and Stewardship

What is the difference between weather and climate?

Climate, weather, soil, and stewardship are all interconnected factors that play critical roles in sustaining human life. Consider these brief definitions that we will explore more deeply in this section. 

●      Climate refers to the long-term patterns of temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind, and other atmospheric conditions in a particular region.

●      Weather represents the short-term atmospheric conditions in a specific location at a given time, including temperature, humidity, precipitation, wind speed, and atmospheric pressure.

●      Soils are the foundation of terrestrial ecosystems, providing essential nutrients, water retention, support for plant growth, and habitat for organisms.

●      Stewardship refers to the responsible management and conservation of natural resources, ecosystems, and biodiversity for the benefit of present and future generations.

This week, we will explore the intricate interplay between climate, weather, soils, and stewardship, and their profound implications for sustaining human life on our planet. Each of these elements serves as a cornerstone in understanding the delicate balance of Earth's ecosystems and the intricate web of relationships that support life. By delving into these topics, we endeavor to gain a deeper appreciation for the interconnectedness of our world and to uncover actionable insights that empower us to foster resilience, promote sustainability, and safeguard the well-being of current and future generations. 

Weather and climate

●      How do weather and climate affect plant growth? 

●      What are the basic principles that account for differences in climate around the world? 

●      How do our choices affect our atmosphere? 

Weather refers to the short-term atmospheric conditions experienced in a specific location over a relatively brief period, such as hours to days. It includes variables like temperature, humidity, precipitation, wind speed, and atmospheric pressure. Climate, on the other hand, represents the long-term patterns and averages of weather conditions observed over extended periods, typically decades to centuries. It encompasses factors like average temperature, rainfall, and seasonal variations, providing a broader perspective on atmospheric behavior and trends.

Weather conditions directly impact plant growth and development on a short-term basis. For example, temperature fluctuations can influence metabolic processes and growth rates, while precipitation levels affect soil moisture availability and plant hydration. In contrast, climate sets the overall environmental conditions that influence plant distribution and adaptation over longer timeframes. It determines factors like the length of the growing season, frost-free periods, and overall moisture regimes, shaping the types of plants that can thrive in a particular region.

Several factors contribute to variations in climate worldwide. These include latitude, proximity to large bodies of water, elevation, ocean currents, atmospheric circulation patterns, topography, and human activity.

Latitude: The angle of sunlight received at different latitudes influences temperature and climate patterns. Regions near the equator receive more direct sunlight and experience warmer temperatures, while polar regions receive less direct sunlight and tend to be colder.

 

Diagram showing the same amount of sunlight hitting different latitudes of Earth's surface. Image by

 

Proximity to large bodies of water: Coastal areas and regions near oceans or seas experience maritime climates characterized by milder temperatures, higher humidity, and moderated seasonal variations due to the heat capacity of water.

Elevation: Higher elevations generally exhibit cooler temperatures due to decreased atmospheric pressure and thinner air, resulting in distinct climate zones and temperature gradients with altitude.

Ocean currents: Ocean currents redistribute heat around the globe, influencing regional climates by affecting temperature, humidity, and precipitation patterns. For example, the Gulf Stream warms Western Europe, while cold currents off the coast of California contribute to cooler temperatures.

 

Ocean currents. Image: US army, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons.

Atmospheric circulation patterns: Global wind patterns, such as the Hadley, Ferrel, and Polar cells, as well as local wind systems, influence climate by redistributing heat and moisture across the Earth's surface, affecting temperature gradients and precipitation patterns.

Topography: Features such as mountains, valleys, and plains influence local climate by altering wind patterns, creating rain shadows, and affecting temperature gradients.

Human activities: Human activities, including the burning of fossil fuels, industrial processes, deforestation, and agricultural practices, release greenhouse gases (such as carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide) and air pollutants into the atmosphere. These emissions contribute to air pollution, climate change, and environmental destruction, with far-reaching consequences for ecosystems, weather patterns, and human health. Sustainable choices, such as transitioning to renewable energy sources, implementing emission reduction measures, and promoting conservation efforts, can alleviate these impacts and safeguard the health of our atmosphere.

 

Greenhouse Effect. Image: US EPA, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Soils

●      What is soil and how is it formed? 

●      What functions does soil perform? 

●      What is the best soil composition? 

●      Horizon A is the most important for plant growth. According to the reading, why do you think this is the case?

Soil is a complex mixture of minerals, organic matter, water, air, and living organisms that forms at the Earth's surface through the weathering of rocks and the decomposition of organic materials over time. It serves as a crucial natural resource that supports plant growth, sustains terrestrial ecosystems, regulates water and nutrient cycles, and provides habitats for various organisms.

 

Different soils. Image: Oregon Department of Transportation, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

The difference between soil and dirt lies in their composition and context. Soil refers to the natural, nutrient-rich material that supports plant life and sustains ecosystems, whereas dirt typically denotes loose, unstructured material lacking in organic matter and nutrients, often considered unwanted or unsightly.

Soil performs several essential functions, including:

●      Providing a medium for plant growth by anchoring roots, supplying nutrients, and regulating water  availability.

●      Supporting diverse biological communities, including microorganisms, insects, and small animals, that  contribute to nutrient cycling, decomposition, and soil health.

●      Regulating water infiltration, storage, and drainage, influencing local hydrology, groundwater recharge,  and flood mitigation.

●      Acting as a carbon sink, storing, and cycling organic carbon, thereby mitigating climate change.

●       Filtering, buffering, and detoxifying pollutants, improving water quality, and reducing     environmental contamination.

Soils differ from place to place due to factors such as parent material, climate, topography, biological activity, and time. These factors influence the soil formation processes, including weathering, erosion, deposition, and organic matter accumulation, leading to the development of distinct soil properties, profiles, and classifications. These differences are important because they influence soil properties such as texture, structure, fertility, and drainage, which in turn affect plant growth, ecosystem functioning, water availability, and agricultural productivity. While there is no single "best" soil composition, loam (a balanced mixture of sand, silt, and clay) is often considered ideal for agriculture due to its favorable physical properties and nutrient-holding capacity.

Scientists test the “healthiness” of soils analyzing soil horizons. Soil horizons refer to the distinct layers or zones that develop over time through the process of soil formation. These horizons are characterized by differences in color, texture, structure, organic matter content, and mineral composition. The most important soil horizon for plant growth is Horizon A, also known as topsoil, which contains the highest concentration of organic matter, nutrients, and beneficial microorganisms necessary for supporting plant roots and sustaining crop growth.

Soil Loss

Briefly define and explain the significance of the following: 

●      Salinization 

●      Desertification 

●      Erosion 

●      Contamination 

●      Urbanization 

What are some of the results of soil destruction?  

Good soils are closely tied to food security as they provide the foundation for agricultural productivity, crop yield, and global food production. Healthy soils support diverse plant communities, nutrient cycling, water retention, and soil fertility, which are essential for sustaining crop growth, livelihoods, and food systems worldwide. There are at least five reasons or processes that destroy soils: salinization, desertification, erosion, contamination, and urbanization.

●      Salinization refers to the accumulation of soluble salts in the soil profile, typically due to irrigation practices, waterlogging, or natural processes. This buildup of salts can lead to soil degradation, reduced plant growth, and loss of agricultural productivity, posing a threat to food security and livelihoods in affected areas.

●      Desertification is the process by which fertile land becomes increasingly arid, degraded, and unable to support vegetation, often because of human activities such as overgrazing, deforestation, poor land management, and climate change. Desertification threatens soil productivity, biodiversity, and ecosystem services, exacerbating land degradation and food insecurity in vulnerable regions.

●      Erosion is the removal and transport of soil particles by wind, water, ice, or gravity, leading to the loss of fertile topsoil, reduced soil productivity, and environmental degradation. Soil erosion can occur naturally or because of human activities such as deforestation, overgrazing, improper land use, and urbanization, posing risks to agricultural sustainability, water quality, and ecosystem health.

●      Contamination refers to the introduction of harmful substances or pollutants into the soil, typically through industrial activities, mining, agriculture, waste disposal, or chemical spills. Soil contamination can degrade soil quality, impair plant growth, and pose risks to human health, wildlife, and ecosystems, highlighting the importance of soil conservation and pollution prevention measures.

●      Urbanization is the process of urban growth and expansion, leading to the conversion of natural landscapes and agricultural land into urban areas, infrastructure, and built environments. Urbanization alters soil properties, land use patterns, and ecosystem functions, contributing to soil degradation, loss of biodiversity, and fragmentation of habitats, particularly in rapidly urbanizing regions.    

Urbanization

●      What are some of the reasons why urbanization occurs?  

●      What are some ways to mitigate the negative effects of urbanization? 

 

As urbanization continues to accelerate and cities expand into surrounding areas, the landscape of agricultural production undergoes profound transformations. Farms, once nestled close to city centers, now find themselves pushed to the outskirts or converted into non-productive land to accommodate urban sprawl. The migration of populations from rural areas to urban centers is a defining feature of modern society. As towns and cities continue to expand, urbanization plays a pivotal role in shaping our communities and the way we live. It represents a profound shift in human settlement patterns, with implications for social, economic, and environmental dynamics. Happening at the same time is shifting climatic conditions, characterized by rising temperatures and altered precipitation patterns, challenge the viability of traditional crop cultivation in certain regions, rendering once-fertile lands less hospitable to agriculture.

Still, cities serve as hubs of opportunity, offering access to employment, education, healthcare, and cultural amenities. They foster innovation, creativity, and diversity, driving economic growth and development. Urbanization is a response to the increasing complexities of modern life, as people seek better livelihoods, improved standards of living, and greater connectivity.

However, urbanization also presents significant challenges. Rapid population growth strains infrastructure and services, leading to congestion, pollution, and resource depletion. Inadequate housing, inequality, and social exclusion are prevalent issues in many urban areas, exacerbating poverty and vulnerability. Environmental degradation, including air and water pollution, loss of green spaces, and climate change, further threaten the sustainability of cities.

To address these challenges and create sustainable cities and communities, innovative solutions and collaborative efforts are essential. This involves urban planning and design that prioritizes resilience, inclusivity, and environmental stewardship. Sustainable transportation systems, affordable housing, green spaces, and efficient resource management are integral components of urban sustainability.

As we discuss the significance of urbanization and sustainable cities, it's important to reflect on its relevance to broader initiatives, including the building of Zion. The principles of community building, cooperation, and stewardship inherent in urban sustainability align with the values of unity, equality, and compassion emphasized in efforts to build Zion communities worldwide. By fostering sustainable cities and communities, we not only enhance quality of life for current residents but also contribute to the collective vision of creating a more just, equitable, and harmonious society for all.

Stewardship

●      What is stewardship?  

●      What are the key principles of stewardship?

 

The principles underpinning sustainable urban development are deeply intertwined with the concept of stewardship — the responsible and caring management of our resources and environment. Just as sustainable cities prioritize the well-being of their inhabitants and the preservation of natural ecosystems, stewardship calls upon us to extend this ethos of care and responsibility to the broader planet. In the pursuit of building Zion communities, where unity, equality, and compassion reign, the values of stewardship become paramount. As stewards of the Earth, we are entrusted with the task of nurturing and safeguarding our planet for present and future generations, ensuring that the blessings of abundance and harmony are shared equitably among all inhabitants. Thus, by embracing the principles of sustainability and stewardship, we not only advance the vision of sustainable cities but also contribute to the realization of a more just, compassionate, and sustainable world, in alignment with the ideals of Zion.

Having stewardship over our planet means taking responsibility for the care, preservation, and sustainable management of Earth's natural resources, ecosystems, and environment. Stewardship involves recognizing the intrinsic value of the Earth and understanding our interconnectedness with all living beings and the environment. It encompasses a sense of duty to protect and conserve biodiversity, maintain ecological balance, and ensure the well-being of present and future generations.

Stewardship extends beyond individual actions to encompass collective efforts at local, national, and global levels. It requires making informed choices and taking proactive measures to minimize environmental degradation, alleviate climate change, and promote sustainability in areas such as energy consumption, waste management, land use, and resource extraction.

Key principles of stewardship include:

●      Conservation: Preserving natural habitats, species diversity, and ecosystems to maintain ecological integrity and biodiversity.

●      Sustainable resource use: Using Earth's resources in a way that meets current needs without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

●      Environmental responsibility: Minimizing pollution, reducing carbon emissions, and adopting eco-friendly practices to minimize harm to the environment.

●      Ethical treatment: Respecting the rights and welfare of all living beings, including animals, plants, and future generations, in decision-making processes.

●      Advocacy and activism: Engaging in advocacy efforts, community initiatives, and policy advocacy to promote environmental protection, conservation, and sustainable development.

Ultimately, stewardship involves fostering a deep sense of reverence, appreciation, and gratitude for the Earth and its natural wonders, recognizing that we are entrusted with the custodianship of this planet and have a moral obligation to act as responsible caretakers for the benefit of all life forms and the health of the planet.

Water Conservation

●      Why is it important to conserve fresh water? 

●      What are some ways we can protect water as an essential resource?  

 

Viewing water conservation through this broader lens of environmental stewardship underscores how our individual actions have far-reaching impacts. When we waste or pollute water supplies, we are not just depleting a resource - we are jeopardizing entire ecosystems and the well-being of all living things, including future generations inheriting this planet. Adopting an ethos of care and mindfulness toward water use becomes an act of respect for the Earth's ecological balance.

Conversely, when we diligently conserve water and keep it clean, we are fulfilling our duty as caretakers of this world. We are ensuring water security for communities globally and allowing nature's water cycle to continue replenishing and sustaining life everywhere. It is an acknowledgement that Earth's precious resources are not ours to own, but to responsibly manage during our mere sojourn on this planet.

Water is essential for sustaining all life on our planet. As human populations continue to grow and demand for freshwater increases, it becomes ever more critical to conserve and protect our limited water resources. This section will explore the vital importance of water conservation and being responsible stewards of this precious natural resource.

We must understand the global water cycle and how fresh water is continually recycled through evaporation, condensation, and precipitation. While the total amount of water on Earth remains relatively constant, only about 3% is fresh water that humans and most ecosystems can use. The majority is salt water in the oceans. Of that 3% fresh water, about two-thirds is frozen in glaciers and polar ice caps. This leaves only about 1% of the world's total water supply available as surface water in lakes, rivers, and groundwater that we can access for drinking, agriculture, and industrial uses.

With such limited freshwater availability, conservation efforts are critical. Overuse, waste, and contamination of fresh water sources can lead to water scarcity crises, famine, disease outbreaks, and conflicts over access to dwindling supplies. Conserving water helps ensure sustainable access for all communities, preserves environmental ecosystems, and safeguards this vital resource for future generations.

Some key principles and practices for water conservation include:

●     Increasing efficiency of water use in agriculture, industry, and homes

●     Fixing leaks in water distribution systems

●     Installing low-flow fixtures and drought-resistant landscaping

●     Recycling and safely reusing grey water when possible

●     Protecting watersheds and wetlands that filter pollutants

In addition to reducing demand, it is crucial to keep water supplies clean by preventing contamination from pesticides, industrial waste, sewage, and other pollutants. Safeguarding water quality helps avoid waterborne diseases and protects aquatic ecosystems that millions of species rely upon.

Individuals, communities, corporations, and governments all have a shared responsibility to use our finite freshwater resources sustainably. Through conservation efforts, improved resource management, and protecting water purity, we can become better stewards of this invaluable resource that all life depends upon.

W02 Sustaining Life Project Introduction 

This week you will complete Part 1 of the Sustaining Life Project (hereafter referred to as Project) and will identify a problem in the world, your nation, community, family or own life. Consider what it would take to start solving this problem on both a large and small scale. When you have identified a possible solution, select a more specific research question related to how you will implement your solution.  Every contribution, no matter how small, helps move us closer to solving the bigger challenge.

 

For inspiration, please read below about William Kamkwamba and how as a 14-year-old boy he harnessed the wind to bring electricity and power to his village (or watch his TedTalk). If William had been in our GESCI 110 class his large-scale, 10-year project could have been “Bring Energy to Remote Areas in Africa” and his small 3-week project for this course could have been “Power for my home”.

 

William Kamkwamba lives in a small village in Africa. In November 2001, his village experienced a drought and famine. He was forced to drop out of secondary school at 14 because his parents couldn’t afford school fees and food for him and his 6 sisters. Soon the family was down to eating just one meal a day that consisted of three bites each (Mackenzie, 2009).

 

“William turned to the new library at the Wimbe Primary School. A shipment of books from the United States had just been donated. One caught William’s eye: Using Energy. The cover showed a long row of windmills resembling the pinwheels he and his cousin Geoffrey had made as children. When William realized this machine was powered by wind – a plentiful resource in Malawi – he became determined to build one. If successful, he would no longer have to go to bed by 7 p.m. because it was dark. (You must apply to get public utilities in rural areas and some families wait decades for power.) Maybe a windmill could also pump fresh water” (Mackenzie, 2009).

 

William scrounged in salvage yards to find scrap material to build his first windmill. The windmill powered a radio. The next windmill had enough power to light 4 lights in his home and power 2 radios. Eventually, he built three windmills producing enough electricity to provide lighting and to pump water (Mackenzie, 2009).

 

 

Women used to walk an hour and a half to get water and now there is a pump in town thanks to William’s windmills.  After his second TedGlobal, William was able to attend a private school and has sent his sisters, cousins, and neighbors to school to receive an education (Mackenzie, 2009).

 

During the time frame of our course, you will not have time to research and complete a project like Mr. Kamkwamba did when he built a windmill to power his home and village, but there are many things you can do, and you can begin on a meaningful project to help to sustain life where you live.

Increasing production of food over the next 50 years is a vital part of our efforts to effectively care for our growing population. During this week, we will explore the key factors that affect crop production and prospects for change that might help our goal of increasing food production despite increasing urbanization. 

 

How Will We Increase Plant and Animal Production? 

What do plants need to grow? 

This week we will discuss the fascinating history and promising future of plant and animal production, exploring the pivotal role of science in agriculture and its profound impact on the world's food supply. Let’s start with plants first. From the earliest agricultural practices of ancient civilizations to the cutting-edge technologies of modern agribusiness, the cultivation of crops has been central to human survival and progress.

 

For plants to grow and thrive, they require a delicate balance of sunlight, water, nutrients, and healthy soil. Adequate light fuels photosynthesis, while water transports essential nutrients from the soil to the plant, and helps maintain the structure of the plant. Plants also depend on the right soil composition, which provides minerals like nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium that are vital for their growth. Additionally, temperature and air quality play significant roles, as extreme conditions can hinder development. Understanding these basic needs is key to optimizing agricultural production and ensuring sustainable crop yields.

 

With a focus on sustainability, efficiency, and resilience, we explore how advancements in genetics, biotechnology, precision farming, and sustainable agriculture practices are shaping the future of food production.

 

The History of Agriculture 

What were some of the earliest techniques developed that allowed agriculture to thrive?  

The history of agriculture is a testament to human ingenuity and adaptation. Early agricultural practices began around 10,000 years ago when humans transitioned from nomadic hunter-gatherer societies to settled farming communities. These early farmers cultivated all kinds of grains, laying the foundation for modern agriculture. The Fertile Crescent, encompassing parts of modern-day Iraq, Syria, and Turkey, is often cited as the cradle of agriculture, where wheat, barley, and legumes were first cultivated.

As civilizations evolved, so did agricultural techniques. The Egyptians developed irrigation systems to control the flooding of the Nile, while the ancient Chinese practiced crop rotation and utilized iron plows. The Roman Empire introduced large-scale farming and advanced storage methods, enabling them to feed vast populations. These early innovations were critical in supporting the growth of societies and the development of trade networks.

 

The Role of Science in Modern Agriculture 

What are some of the positive results of the Green Revolution?  

The Industrial Revolution marked a significant turning point in agricultural history, bringing mechanization and scientific advancements that transformed farming practices. The introduction of tractors, combine harvesters, and synthetic fertilizers drastically increased productivity and efficiency. These innovations reduced the reliance on manual labor and allowed for the cultivation of larger areas of land.

In the 20th century, the Green Revolution further revolutionized agriculture with the development of high-yielding crop varieties, improved irrigation techniques, and the widespread use of chemical pesticides and fertilizers. These advancements led to dramatic increases in crop production, particularly in developing countries, helping to alleviate hunger and poverty.

Scientific Innovations Shaping the Future of Agriculture 

What is precision agriculture?  

Today's agricultural landscape is being reshaped by a new wave of scientific innovations. Precision farming, biotechnology, and sustainable practices are at the forefront of this transformation.

●      Precision Farming: Precision farming utilizes technologies such as global positioning systems, (GPS), geographic information systems (GIS), drones, and sensor devices to optimize field-level management. These tools provide detailed data on soil conditions, crop health, and weather patterns, enabling farmers to make informed decisions about planting, irrigation, and fertilization. By applying inputs more efficiently, precision farming reduces waste, lowers costs, and minimizes environmental impact.

●      Biotechnology: Advances in biotechnology, including genetic engineering and CRISPR gene editing, are creating crops that are more resilient to pests, diseases, and climate change. Genetically modified organisms (GMOs) like Bt corn and Golden Rice have been developed to improve yield, nutritional content, and resistance to environmental stresses. These innovations hold great promise for enhancing food security and sustainability.

●      Sustainable Agriculture: Sustainable agriculture practices aim to balance productivity with environmental stewardship. Techniques such as conservation tillage, cover cropping, and integrated pest management help preserve soil health, reduce water usage, and decrease chemical inputs. Agroforestry (conservation of trees) and organic farming also play crucial roles in promoting biodiversity and resilience in agricultural systems.

The Impact of Climate Change on Agriculture 

Why is climate change a concern for the future of agriculture? 

Climate change poses significant challenges to agriculture, affecting crop yields, livestock health, and food security. Rising temperatures, shifting precipitation patterns, and increased frequency of extreme weather events disrupt traditional farming practices and necessitate adaptations.

Regions experiencing adverse impacts of climate change, such as arid and semi-arid areas, are likely to see declines in crop production. Conversely, some regions may benefit from milder temperatures and increased rainfall, potentially boosting agricultural output. However, these shifts can exacerbate existing inequalities, with vulnerable populations in already food-insecure regions facing heightened risks of hunger and malnutrition.

Based on data provided by Wageningen Economic Research. 2018. Climate Change and Global Market Integration: Implications for global economic activities, agricultural commodities and food security. SOCO 2018 Background Paper, Rome, FAO. https://openknowledge.fao.org/server/api/core/bitstreams/c2e08845-8f39-4c18-bb1e-4e0e40169e33/content

Adapting to climate change requires a multifaceted approach, including the development of climate-resilient crops, improved water management systems, and policies that support sustainable farming practices. International cooperation and investment in agricultural research are essential to alleviate the impacts of climate change and ensure global food security.

The Future of Food Production 

Describe some of the strategies that can be used to increase efficient food production. 

Looking ahead, the future of food production will be shaped by continued advancements in agricultural technology and practices. Key trends include:

●      Vertical Farming: Vertical farming involves growing crops in stacked layers, often in controlled environments using hydroponics or aeroponics. This method maximizes space efficiency, reduces water usage, and allows for year-round production, making it particularly suitable for urban areas with limited arable land.

●      Renewable Energy: Integrating renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power, into agricultural operations can reduce reliance on fossil fuels and decrease greenhouse gas emissions. Renewable energy technologies can also power irrigation systems and other farm equipment, promoting sustainability.

●      New Crop Varieties: Breeding and genetic engineering will continue to produce new crop varieties tailored to specific climatic conditions and consumer preferences. These crops will be designed to enhance yield, nutritional content, and resistance to pests and diseases.

●      Digital Agriculture: The use of big data, artificial intelligence, and machine learning will revolutionize agricultural decision-making. These technologies can analyze vast amounts of data to optimize planting schedules, predict crop yields, and manage supply chains, increasing efficiency and reducing waste.

The journey through the history and future of plant production highlights the critical role of science in agriculture. From ancient innovations to modern technological advancements, agriculture has continually evolved to meet the needs of a growing population. As we face new challenges such as climate change and food security, scientific innovation will be essential in developing sustainable, efficient, and resilient agricultural systems.

Introduction to GMOs 

●      What are GMOs? 

●      How is crossbreeding used to develop new plant varieties? 

 

Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) are organisms whose genetic material has been altered using biotechnology to introduce specific traits that are advantageous for agriculture. This technology allows scientists to enhance certain characteristics in plants, animals, and microorganisms that would be challenging or impossible to achieve through traditional breeding methods. By inserting genes from one species into another, GMOs can be engineered to exhibit traits such as pest resistance, improved nutritional content, and increased yield, offering significant potential benefits for food production and global food security.

In contrast, crossbreeding is a more traditional method used to develop new plant varieties by selecting and breeding plants with desirable traits over multiple generations. For example, farmers might cross two varieties of wheat, one resistant to disease and the other with higher yields, to produce a new variety that combines both qualities. While crossbreeding relies on natural reproductive processes between compatible species, it is a slower method compared to genetic modification and is limited to traits that exist within the gene pool of the species being bred. Crossbreeding has been instrumental in developing hardy crops with improved resilience to environmental conditions and enhanced nutritional profiles, but it cannot achieve the same precision or range of possibilities as GMOs.

Examples of GMOs 

●      Bt corn is genetically engineered to produce a toxin derived from bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis, which is harmful to certain pests like the European corn borer. This modification reduces the need for chemical pesticides.

●      Golden Rice is fortified with vitamin A by incorporating genes from daffodils and bacteria. This biofortified crop is designed to combat vitamin A deficiency, which is prevalent in many developing countries and can lead to blindness and other health issues.

●      Roundup Ready Soybeans are modified to be resistant to glyphosate, a common herbicide. This allows farmers to control weeds more effectively without damaging the crop.

Pros of GMOs 

●      Increased Crop Yields: GMOs can be engineered to grow faster and produce higher yields, helping to meet the food demands of a growing global population.

●      Pest and Disease Resistance: Crops can be modified to be resistant to pests and diseases, reducing the need for chemical pesticides and minimizing crop losses.

●      Enhanced Nutritional Content: GMOs like Golden Rice can be enriched with vitamins and minerals, addressing nutritional deficiencies in populations that rely heavily on staple crops.

●      Environmental Benefits: Reduced reliance on chemical pesticides and herbicides can lead to lower environmental contamination and promote sustainable farming practices.

Cons of GMOs 

●      Environmental Concerns: The introduction of GMOs into the environment can potentially disrupt ecosystems. For example, pest-resistant crops could affect non-target organisms and lead to the development of resistant pests.

●      Economic Issues: The dominance of a few biotech companies in the GMO market can lead to increased seed prices and dependence on proprietary technologies, causing a disadvantage to  small-scale and independent farmers.

●      Health Concerns: Although GMOs are generally considered safe by regulatory agencies, some people worry about potential long-term health effects that have not yet been fully studied.

●      Ethical and Labeling Issues: There are ethical concerns regarding the manipulation of genetic material and the transparency of GMO labeling, with consumers demanding the right to know what is in their food.

W02 Study: Animal Production

At the end of this section, students will be able to:

●      Animal Production: Past and Present

○      Describe how the world’s animal product consumption has changed over time and as wealth increases.

○      Identify the tools that have been used to meet the increased demand for meat production up to this time.

○      Identify ethical concerns that need to be addressed with current and emerging technologies.

●      Animal Production: Meeting Future Needs

○      Summarize the arguments in favor and against animal production.

○      Assess the sustainability of animal production practices.

How Will We Increase Animal Production?

More people around the world are adopting a Western lifestyle. The demand for luxury is increasing, and with it, the desire for more animal products. While meat is a very complete source of protein and is nutrient dense, it takes far more resources to produce animal products than plant products. Far more land, water, and other assets are needed. With the growing demand, how will we increase animal production?

The goal of this study section is to learn about tools that can be used in the future to increase availability of animal products such as meat, milk, and eggs to meet the demand of a growing human population. The effects of increased animal production on the environment and the obligation to ensure animal welfare will also be discussed.

Advancements in Animal Production: Efficiency, Health, and Sustainability

How has animal production and consumption changed over time?

The journey of animal production has seen remarkable advancements over the years, driven by a blend of scientific innovation, improved breeding practices, and evolving production systems. These developments have not only enhanced the efficiency of producing high-quality animal-derived foods but have also prioritized the health and well-being of livestock.

Historically, as societies transitioned from subsistence farming to more commercial agricultural practices, the consumption of animal products began to rise significantly. In recent decades, global animal product consumption has surged, particularly in developing countries, as rising incomes and urbanization have changed dietary preferences. Wealthier populations tend to consume more meat, dairy, and eggs, leading to increased demand for these products. This trend is further fueled by globalization, which has made a wider variety of animal products available to consumers around the world.

Here, we explore the multifaceted world of modern animal production, delving into methods for improving quality and efficiency, factors influencing livestock health, the impact of breeding and production practices, and the shifting landscape of consumer preferences. As wealth increases, the focus is also shifting towards sustainability and ethical considerations in animal production, prompting innovations aimed at reducing environmental impact while maintaining the health and welfare of livestock.

 

Methods for Producing Higher-Quality Animal-Derived Foods

 

What methods have been used to produce higher-quality animal-derived foods and fiber products more efficiently?

To produce higher-quality animal-derived foods more efficiently, various methods have been implemented:

●      Selective Breeding: This traditional method involves choosing animals with desirable traits for reproduction, leading to improved offspring over generations. Traits such as faster growth rates, higher milk yield, and better wool quality are targeted.

●      Genetic Engineering: Advances in biotechnology have enabled the modification of animal genomes to enhance specific traits. For example, genetically modified salmon grow faster than their non-GMO counterparts.

●      Improved Nutrition: Optimizing feed formulations to meet the specific nutritional needs of different livestock species enhances growth, productivity, and product quality. This includes the use of feed additives and supplements to promote health and efficiency.

●      Precision Farming: The use of technology to monitor and manage livestock environments more accurately helps improve productivity. This includes automated feeding systems, climate control, and health monitoring tools.

Factors Affecting the Health and Quality of Livestock

Several factors influence the health and quality of livestock, which in turn affects productivity:

●      Nutrition: A balanced diet tailored to the species and life stage of the animal is crucial for maintaining health and optimizing production.

●      Housing and Environment: Proper housing conditions that provide adequate space, ventilation, and hygiene reduce stress and the incidence of disease.

●      Healthcare Management: Regular veterinary care, vaccinations, and parasite control are essential for preventing and managing diseases.

●      Genetics: The genetic makeup of an animal significantly impacts its susceptibility to diseases, growth rate, and quality of products such as meat, milk, and wool.

●      Management Practices: Efficient and humane management practices, including handling and transportation, play a critical role in maintaining animal welfare and product quality.

Impact of Breeding Practices on Productivity

Changes in breeding practices have led to significant increases in animal productivity:

●      Artificial Insemination: This technique allows for the widespread use of superior genetics from top-performing males, increasing the overall quality of offspring.

●      Embryo Transfer: This method enables the rapid multiplication of superior females by transferring embryos from high-quality donors to surrogate mothers.

●      Crossbreeding: Combining different breeds to capitalize on hybrid vigor can result in animals that are more robust and productive than their purebred counterparts.

●      Genomic Selection: Utilizing genomic information to select animals with the best genetic potential accelerates the breeding process and enhances productivity.

Evolution of Production Systems

How have changes in production systems led to increased productivity in animals?

Modern production systems have evolved to boost productivity and efficiency:

●      Intensive Farming: High-density livestock farming with controlled environments maximizes output per unit area. Examples include concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs).

●      Integrated Farming Systems: Combining livestock and crop production creates synergies, such as using animal manure as fertilizer, which enhances overall farm productivity.

●      Technology Integration: Automation and data analytics are used to optimize every aspect of animal production, from feeding to health monitoring, leading to more efficient operations.

Scale of Animal Production

Today, large-scale producers dominate the animal production industry. These producers benefit from economies of scale, advanced technologies, and access to extensive resources, allowing them to produce food animals more efficiently and cost-effectively than small-scale farmers.

 

Animal health is important for several reasons:

●      Productivity: Healthy animals grow faster, reproduce more efficiently, and produce higher-quality products.

●      Food Safety: Healthy livestock are less likely to harbor diseases that can be transmitted to humans, ensuring a safer food supply.

●      Economic Viability: Preventing and managing diseases reduces veterinary costs and losses due to mortality, improving the overall profitability of the farming operation.

The use of artificial hormones in animal production, such as growth promoters, has been a subject of debate:

●      Benefits: Hormones can enhance growth rates, improve feed efficiency, and increase milk production, leading to higher productivity.

●      Concerns: There are concerns about the potential health effects on humans consuming hormone-treated products and the ethical implications of their use. Additionally, there is a risk of hormones entering the environment and impacting ecosystems.

●      Regulations: Many countries have strict regulations governing the use of hormones in livestock production to ensure food safety and public health.

Consumer preferences for meat production are increasingly leaning towards sustainability, animal welfare, and health considerations:

●      Demand for Organic and Natural Products: Consumers are willing to pay a premium for meat products labeled as organic, free-range, or grass-fed, which they perceive as healthier and more ethical.

●      Interest in Plant-Based Alternatives: The rise in popularity of plant-based and lab-grown meat products reflects a growing concern for health, environmental sustainability, and animal welfare.

●      Transparency and Traceability: Consumers seek transparency in production practices and prefer products from sources that provide clear information about animal welfare and farming methods.

Producers must adapt to these trends by implementing practices that align with consumer values, such as adopting more humane treatment of animals, reducing the use of antibiotics, and focusing on sustainable production methods.

Goals of Sustainable Agriculture

Sustainable agriculture aims to balance the need for food production with environmental health, economic viability, and social responsibility. Key goals include:

●      Environmental Protection: Implementing practices that conserve natural resources, reduce pollution, and promote biodiversity.

●      Economic Viability: Ensuring that farming remains profitable and can support the livelihoods of farmers and their communities.

●      Social Equity: Providing fair labor conditions, supporting rural communities, and ensuring access to nutritious food for all populations.

By focusing on these goals, sustainable agriculture seeks to create a resilient and equitable food system that can meet the needs of present and future generations.

Which Type of Livestock is the Most Feed Efficient?

Feed efficiency, a critical measure in livestock production, determines how effectively animals convert feed into desired outputs like milk, eggs, or meat. Among various livestock, broiler chickens are typically the most feed-efficient, followed by laying hens, growing pigs, dairy cows, and beef steers. This efficiency is largely due to the biological and metabolic differences among species (feed calculation efficiencies are shown below).

●      Broiler Chickens have an exceptional Feed Efficiency Ratio (FER), often around 1.5 to 2.0. This means for every 1.5 to 2 pounds of feed, the chicken produces 1 pound of meat. Their rapid growth rates and high feed-to-meat conversion efficiency make them a preferred choice for meat production.

●      Laying Hens also exhibit high feed efficiency, with a ratio typically ranging from 2.0 to 2.5. They efficiently convert feed into eggs, making them valuable for egg production.

●      Growing Pigs have a moderate feed efficiency, usually between 2.5 and 3.5. They convert feed into meat effectively, but less efficiently than poultry.

●      Dairy Cows have a feed efficiency ratio for milk production of around 1.3 to 1.5. This indicates that for every 1.3 to 1.5 pounds of feed, the cow produces 1 pound of milk. Their efficiency in milk production is due to specialized breeding and optimal feeding practices.

●      Beef Steers have a feed efficiency ratio of approximately 6 to 8. This lower efficiency is due to their longer growth periods and higher maintenance energy requirements compared to poultry and pigs.

 

How Can You Improve the Efficiency of an Animal?

Improving feed efficiency in livestock involves several strategies:

●      Genetic Selection: Selecting and breeding animals with naturally higher feed efficiency can lead to significant improvements over generations. Genetic markers for feed efficiency can be identified and utilized in breeding programs.

●      Optimal Nutrition: Providing a balanced diet tailored to the specific nutritional needs of the animal at different growth stages can enhance feed efficiency. High-quality feed with the right balance of proteins, carbohydrates, fats, vitamins, and minerals is essential.

●      Health Management: Maintaining animal health through regular veterinary care, vaccination programs, and disease prevention strategies reduces the energy animals need to combat illnesses, thus improving feed conversion.

●      Environmental Control: Ensuring animals live in an environment with optimal temperature, humidity, and minimal stress improves feed intake and conversion. Comfortable housing, adequate space, and good ventilation are key factors.

●      Feed Additives: The use of feed additives like enzymes, probiotics, and prebiotics can enhance digestive efficiency and nutrient absorption, leading to better feed conversion.

○       

Feed Efficiency Ratio (FER)

●      Feed Efficiency Ratio (FER) is calculated using the formula:

FER = Output (Milk, Eggs, Meat)/ Input (Feed or Grain)

●      A higher FER indicates greater feed efficiency. The calculation involves measuring the total output of the animal in terms of milk, eggs, or meat and dividing it by the total feed intake.

Calculating Feed Conversion Efficiency

Let's calculate the feed conversion efficiency for different types of livestock using the following example data:

 

Output (Milk, Eggs, Meat)

Input (Feed or Grain)

FER

Dairy Cow

60 pounds of milk

90 pounds of feed

60 / 90 = 0.67

Beef Steer

3 pounds of meat

24 pounds of feed

3 / 24 = 0.125

Growing Pig

1.8 pounds of meat

5.4 pounds of feed

1.8 / 5.4 = 0.33

Broiler Chicken

0.2 pounds of meat

0.4 pounds of feed

0.2 / 0.4 = 0.5

Laying Hen

0.25 pounds of eggs

0.6 pounds of feed

0.25 / 0.6 = 0.42

 

Interpretation and Analysis

From the calculated FER values, it's evident that dairy cows are the most feed-efficient, followed by broiler chickens, laying hens, growing pigs, and beef steers. These values highlight the efficiency differences across species and emphasize the importance of selecting the right animal for specific production goals.

Understanding and improving feed efficiency in livestock is pivotal for sustainable and profitable animal production. By focusing on genetic selection, optimal nutrition, health management, environmental control, and the judicious use of feed additives, producers can enhance the feed efficiency of their livestock. Calculating and analyzing Feed Efficiency Ratios provides valuable insights into the effectiveness of these strategies and aids in making informed decisions for better resource utilization and productivity.

Efforts to improve feed efficiency not only benefit individual producers but also contribute to broader goals of sustainability and resource conservation in agriculture. Reduced feed inputs mean lower production costs, less environmental impact from feed production, and a more efficient use of land and resources. Moreover, efficient animal production can help meet the increasing global demand for food while minimizing the ecological footprint of agriculture.

Ultimately, optimizing feed efficiency is not just about maximizing output but also about promoting animal health and welfare. A balanced approach that considers the needs of the animals, the environment, and society is essential for building a resilient and sustainable food system. By embracing science-based practices and adopting a holistic view of livestock production, we can ensure the well-being of animals, safeguard the environment, and meet the nutritional needs of a growing global population

The Role of Beef Cattle in Sustainable Agriculture

What other factors should be considered (besides FER) when evaluating the efficiency of beef?

While calculating the Feed Efficiency Ratio (FER) for beef steers may indeed yield a value indicating lower efficiency compared to other livestock species, it's essential to consider the unique role that beef cattle play in our food system.

Unlike poultry and pigs, which directly compete with humans for grains and other food resources, beef cattle primarily consume forages and other feedstuffs that are not suitable for human consumption. These animals are ruminants, meaning they have a specialized digestive system capable of efficiently converting fibrous plant materials, such as grass and hay, into high-quality protein through microbial fermentation in their rumen.

This distinction is crucial when evaluating the efficiency of beef production. While the FER for beef steers may appear higher due to the longer time required for them to reach market weight and the relatively lower feed conversion efficiency compared to poultry or pigs, it's essential to recognize that beef cattle are converting resources that are not directly consumable by humans into valuable protein.

Additionally, beef production often plays a vital role in sustainable land management and ecosystem preservation. Grazing cattle help maintain grasslands and other natural habitats, promoting biodiversity and carbon sequestration. Managed grazing systems can improve soil health, water retention, and overall ecosystem resilience, contributing to environmental sustainability.

In summary, while beef cattle may have a lower FER compared to other livestock species, their unique ability to convert low-quality forages into high-quality protein, coupled with their role in sustainable land management, must be considered when evaluating their efficiency and contribution to our food system.

Animal Efficiency Calculations

Which type of livestock is the most feed efficient? How can you improve the efficiency of an animal? Animals can be evaluated on how efficiently they convert the feed they eat into food for people.  Feed Efficiency Ratio (FER) is a ratio of output divided by input. Remember that for this calculation the larger the number of the ratio the more efficient the animal. Because it is a ratio, there is more than one way to get a high efficiency: either by increasing the output or decreasing the input.

In this activity, you will calculate the feed conversion efficiency of a dairy cow, beef steer, growing pig, broiler chicken, and laying hen by dividing output by feed intake using the following equation:

Feed Efficiency Ratio = Output (Milk, Eggs, Meat) / Input (Feed or Grain)

Week 03: How We Make Educated Food Choices 

In Week 03, we will be learning about how and why our diets have changed over the last 100 years. We will also be exploring food preservation techniques and methods to decrease bacteria and food hazards. This week we will also be learning about nutrition and making educated food choices. You will have the opportunity to do a three-day food journal to track the foods you currently are eating and compare it to the recommended servings of the different food groups.
